ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained a broader understanding of the Disney enterprise and just how many facets of the world it touches on. Everything from economics, politics, body image, film, etc.
a super interdisciplinary approach to Disney as a company (there's no real limit to what we can discuss)
I learned all about Disney and its films and parks and economics and politics and literally everything
Learnt about a range of subject areas through the lens of Disney, and also about the Disney enterprise.
I learned much about all aspects of Disney that I know before

I learned a lot about how Disney markets its products, what themes are explored in the Disney films, and how they are implementing their agenda as they move forward in regards to being more inclusive.
A survey of all aspects of Disney - from history of the parks, Disney movies, globalization, environmental impact, DEI representation and more

This was an exploratory course that covered very different subjects and topics, so I walk away with a well rounded view of the history, politics, economics, and social critiques of Disney. I learned how to do film analysis, think about important questions like authorial intent and the strengths and weaknesses of academia, and I left knowing a lot more about what goes behind Disney, it's parks, and media.
Fantastic course!! I gained critical thinking skills to analyze the influence of the Disney company

I learned all the intricacies of Disney! This course goes beyond surface-level information to understand the intricacies of the company, to truly understand all the roles this company has in our world.

I learned so much about so many aspects of Disney that I wasn't familiar with before from economics to theme park operations. It encouraged me to think more critically about major corporations like Disney and how to engage with content that might not usually be included in academic discussions.
Critical engagement with media and the ability to critically evaluate its positive, negative, and neutral impact on all aspects of life (environment, education, economy, politics)

This course allowed me to really exposed me to various academic disciplines that I had previously never had the chance to explore, through the medium of Disney. I think one of the most essential skills I gained in this course was the ability to take theoretical concepts and apply them to real-life issues. Because the course did not limit itself to one particular academic discipline, it allowed for a inter-disciplinary exploration of issues within Disney that added a lot of depth and layer to my learning.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: diverse subject matter! Weaknesses: Some discussions felt very surface level (but that's what happens when you touch on a wide variety of topics).

Strengths: such a great classroom environment fostered by Prof. Battle, she made room for fun in the class and for being serious but always with good-faith assumptions in discussing the hard things, assignments never felt tedious (always realistic and super creative in the paper topics) such a cool class that really embodies the residential college seminar program to the utmost degree, paper feedback was helpful, being super interdisciplinary made this class so awesome to discover new things and new lenses

weaknesses: some weeks were less interesting than others but I know that's a result of the students' varying interests so that's understandable, maybe a lil bit of feedback on reading responses (feedback was only given if improvement was necessary)
Really enjoyed the class but the amount of reading we had to do was oftentimes a lot which got kinda stressful.
Really enjoyed the structure of the course and found the class both engaging and interesting.
Great group discussions and sharing of opinions

While there were a lot of readings for this course, each one was engaging and added something to the discussion. Overall, this course was very effective in terms of the format and the content. Each week introduced a new topic related to Disney, making the interdisciplinary nature of the course a huge plus point.

The course was designed well for student learning. I especially liked the group discussion part of the class both small and large groups. I did feel there was a lot of reading some of which was not covered in class.

S: Professor Battle is amazing, she's kind, professional, and very knowledgable. She lets everyone be heard, and she prepares her presentations wonderfully. She's very open to feedback. The class is very fun, from the different subjects, to the weekly movies, to the out of the box projects/papers. The class is designed to let you explore what you're interested in. 
W: Personally I found there to be a little bit too much of an emphasis on race and gender representation, which was a common theme throughout the class. I think there's a lot of other topics that could've been covered (religion, film making process, etc). We also primarily focus on animated films, so if you're looking to study Disney Channel or other off shoots, you'd have to do it in your projects.
Fantastic course! Loved the discussions and I was very engaged with the class. Guest speaker with Dr. Cheu was fantastic
This course was filled with so many wonderful discussions! It was fantastic to talk about new topics surrounding Disney every week!!

Their class is one of a kind. Every single week we had discussions that I wouldn't get in any other classroom with a group of students and a professor who all loved the content. The variety of topics covered was a strength. This probably the only class where I can say I wish we met more than once each week because there was so much to talk about.

strengths: well prepared class powerpoints that were impossible to not develop into rich discussions; interdisciplinary; creative assignments 

weaksnesses: none!

Strengths: The class size being relatively small allowed for engaging discussions. There was a lot of flexibility in the learning process. Especially for our final project, we were each able to delve further into areas that we were personally interested in. 
Weakness: The class was only once a week, but there was a lot to cover, so sometimes it felt rushed.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: For sure
If you are interested in Disney, I recommend it! It was a great course to supplement other classwork. The Professor is lovely and does a great job making the class environment fun for everyone!

Absolutely, this is a must-take for anyone interested in Disney. Honestly such a blessing of a class that really sheds light on the complexities (the good and the bad and the in-between). It's easy to be a critic but there's value is seeing what Disney has accomplished too. A true dream of a class for my senior spring and I wish more classes were like this on.
If youre into Disney yep.
Yes! It was a fantastic class, I enjoyed everything we learnt about and felt that I learnt a lot throughout the semester.
Yes I would! This class was my favorite class at Yale! There were so many interesting discussions and the projects and papers were so fun. We were able to be so creative

I would highly recommend this course to anyone who is looking to explore Disney from many different angles (its role as a corporation, the ongoing political tension, marketing and psychology, etc.). This was an extremely engaging and enlightening course.

If you love Disney and can get in, take it! Not just for Disney adults but anyone curious to engage in critical studies with a modern application. Huge flexibility on papers too so can be designed to your interests
Yes. Students who are interested or passionate about Disney should take this class.

I would highly recommend this class. The course subject is so interesting, and you may never get another chance to study Disney from the angles in this course. You learn soon that Disney is much much bigger, pervasive, and powerful in American culture, economics, and politics, than you thought. It's a fun class, Professor Battle is amazing, and you can't go wrong. She makes you feel welcome and brings Disney to the classroom!
Yes! Perfect course!

This was an amazing course, especially considering this was the first year it was taught! Prof. Battle is an extremely kind, thoughtful, and understanding professor and you can tell how much effort she puts into each lecture. My favorite thing about this course is how interdisciplinary it was-- each week we explored a different topic relating to Disney, such as environmentalism, Florida politics, economic impact, diversity in film, etc. It is unique in that students from a wide variety of backgrounds and majors can engage with the material in different ways and have their opinions heard in this seminar format. Overall, I would definitely recommend this course to anyone who loves Disney and wants to take a look at some of their classic characters, movies, and rides from a more critical lens in a super fun and engaging way.
Yes, definitely! Even if you are not a big fan of Disney, this course gives you a lot of valuable information since the company is so influential in our world.

Absolutely. I hope they decide to offer this course again. Students from all backgrounds can appreciate this class. You get to revisit films and content you love while also being encouraged to think about it in a new light.
Yes! Absolutely! Was the perfect way to end my time at Yale

I would 2000% recommend this course to anyone. I think the course is enjoyable to anyone from essentially any major, as it really pushes you to think beyond one academic discipline. Even if you are not a fan of Disney, or do not have any prior knowledge of Disney, I think Disney was the perfect company to focus on (there is so much to explore from gender studies to economics to politics to art). The course is really interesting, and the professor did an amazing job to keep the class engaged every week.
